@AnanthaKrishnanKG, I remember initially I wanted to use a immoral DB, then I changed the DB service to cloudant DB service, and changed my whisk.properties file accordingly.
db.provider=Cloudant
db.prefix=vagrant_vincentdemwsk_
db.whisk.actions=vagrant_vincentdemwsk_whisks
db.whisk.auths=subjects
db.host=dliu.cloudant.com
db.port=443
db.username=dliu
db.password=your_password

@rabbah The bug could be that the invoker came up too slowly.  If you look at the log, you see that the second time, it took 10 seconds for it to come up.  The invoker lifecycle PR #495 will help with that.  Another thing is to increase the allowed check time because a local deploy on a loaded machine might just take longer.

@AnanthaKrish I just merged a pull request from @perryibm that should improve the behavior for you. Can you rebase to head and try again?

```
> wsk activation poll -h
usage: wsk activation poll [-h] [-u AUTH] [-e EXIT] [-ss SINCE_SECS]
                           [-sm SINCE_MINS] [-sh SINCE_HRS] [-sd SINCE_DAYS]
                           [name]

positional arguments:
  name                  the namespace to poll
```

The value you provided is interpreted by the CLI as a namespace. Since it's a namespace that doesn't exist, you get an empty activation list.

I'm guessing the compilation fails and, as a result, when the action is run, an error is thrown, not the expected json is returned and the error above is sent to the user. Not sure how to fix this. Perhaps compile the code ahead of time and check it compiled properly and if that's not the case try to send a different error as part of initialization?
note that you will want to re-enable the one from CLISwiftTests as well that I disabled earlier.
can't you wrap with a try and report error as response?

i think this could work? if i recall correctly, the "ugly whisk stack trace" part of the error response gives an indication of the problem, it's just the top level error message whisk returns is deceptive.

hmm, now i'm getting a different response. i'll continue to try to replicate my original error message. this one is pretty close, though it'd be nice to find a way to avoid displaying internal stack traces to the user.

(purposefully not formatting the result. i.e. the "
" strings occur verbatim, not as newlines)

here is the example code i used for my previous comment:

```
/**
  *
  * main() will be invoked when you Run This Action.
  * 
  * @param Whisk actions accept a single parameter,
  *        which must be a JSON object.
  *
  * @return The return value must also be JSON.
  *         It will be the output of this action.
  *
  */
import sys

def main(dict):
    if 'message' in dict:
        name = dict['message']
    else:
        name = 'stranger'
    greeting = 'Hello ' + name + '!'
    print(greeting)
    return {'greeting':greeting}
```

@ioana-blue Looking at the python action, the `init` accepts the input unchecked. I would lift the eval to init and return an appropriate error if it fails: that will allow you to dictate that it was bad code vs a bad run. This should be done anyway so that the code is eval'ed only once for a warm container.

I have interests to fix issue. Please let me know if my understanding is correct.

The goal is to make dockerSkeleton tar ball available here: https://<apihost>/blackbox-0.1.0.tar.gz, then command `wsk sdk install docker` can download dockerSkeleton and works.

The artifacts  related with dockerSkeleton include:

```
catalog/demo/dockerSkeleton
tools/build.xml
tools/cli/publishArtifact.sh
```

My plan is to create a folder in OpenWhisk: tools/blackbox, and put all related artifacts there. It may take me several days to work on it, learning by doing. If you think it's OK, I can take this issue.

Some thoughts on this from a discussion with @domdom82.
- We should get rid of mounting `/var/lib/docker/containers/` in order to get user container logs if possible
- We could introduce a daemon which runs on the host pipes user container logs from `/var/lib/docker/containers` to a separate directory which is then mounted as a volume by the invoker. This daemon could potentially leverage docker events.

This should prevent the error observed. As a step forward on this issue, I will try to reproduce the error in a minimal working example as a playground for experimenting with different approaches to make fast log extraction possible without mounting `/var/lib/docker/containers`.

The CLI output should be beefed up to certainly say that the 'package bind' failed; however, the root cause at this point (i.e. specified package does not exist) should be more clear.  When using CURL, our CLI is out of the picture and the only error details would be in the HTTP response.

@daisy-ycguo I created the repo [openwhisk/openwhisk-sdk-docker](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-sdk-docker)
Let's work together on this to populate with initial content

@mdeuser the controller was missing a case match against this scenario to tailor the error message. I added a path for this in the above patch.

```
wsk package bind nonexistentpkg mypkgbinding
error: binding specified a package that does not exist (code 3)
```

note that code should be renamed at some point - it is a transaction id for the request.
I think we can close this for now. Python has been working with basic tests for a while.

@ioana-blue Could you respond to the comment https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/16#issuecomment-196299872
 from @vmtyler about how "handling the requirements compiling"?

Some thoughts on this:
1.  Why doesn't the error occur for the many other action containers which are routinely  removed from the system?
2. An external agent can overcome the problem but will complicate our container-only principle and make deployment potentially complicated.  The agent will itself need to be restarted and coordinated with the invoker as essentially part of the logic is being moved into another component.
3. If we separate out blackbox containers, it is feasible to avoid logging through docker by having the action container push out its logs by some other means.  This is of course a lot more work but might give us much more control and splitting off blackbox means we are committed to multiple implementation strategies.

@csantanapr does this require updating docs for `cat` vs `split`?

Do we lose any relevant information if we change to a count-per-day/hour strategy?
Off the top of my head I think as a user I would like to be able to backtrack the activations so I could determine if my rules work, i.e. 

```
t1 -> seq1 -> a1 -> a2 -> a3
```

On the other hand I don't even get that "in-order" list using `wsk activation poll` today due to the asynchronous nature of events. 

However it may seem odd that we track activations of other things such as actions exactly, but not triggers. 

What a about a hybrid model where we track all activations individually per day **and as a count** but have automation in place that flushes the "per day" part regularly?

As a user you usually only want to track down individual trigger / action activations as you are developing them. Once they work fine you are more interested in statistical values, i.e. "how many times did my action fire this week" etc. 

By flushing we could take some of the load off of the db.
cool! thanks

> On the other hand I don't even get that "in-order" list using wsk activation poll today due to the asynchronous nature of events.

You surely get trigger before rule before action. If you see otherwise then there's a defect.

Definitely ObjectStorage is the best repository for blob storage but what about using Cloudant attachment as a front end to ObjectStorage?  

We already have excellent cloudant package supporting feed and it should be possible to use Cloudant as a blob storage frontend, automatically exporting the attachment writing the blob on ObjectStorage with a simple whisk action and then remove it from Cloudant.  It should be nice to deliver a sample for that.

A completion message is now sent back from the invoker to the controller and in a few test cases I have seen this happens faster than a cloudant poll as expected.  The next step is to enhance the response with the activation result and for the controller to use this when available to complete a blocking call.

Have we thought about moving away from the "read the logs from file directly" approach yet? I think we had some discussions around splitting the activation in two parts, one being the result + metadata and the other being the logs. If we'ld save the result first and then fetch the logs asynchronously we could move "log getting" off the critical path and use `docker logs` there, as speed doesn't matter that much anymore. That'ld make us interfaced through Docker APIs solely.

The "result" part of an activation is already separate from the logs and has never been part of the log as it is sent back on the POST - along with the metadata.  However, the activation record from the invoker is written once and so it is still on the critical path anyhow.  That's the latency aspect but equally serious is the overall performance issue.   In various versions of docker, we have noted significant delay in other docker operations when `docker log` was in use (both latency and general slowness) and so moved away from it.  This is in relation to both `docker log` and `docker log --follow`.  Of course docker 1.11 might be better but we are not on that yet.

At a higher level, the point of this PR is to unify the way we get logs in the invoker.  Whether we do it from the filesystem or via the docker API, we should not be doing both as we are now.  So I think we should consolidate that first and in the future move (all at once) to possibly other logging mechanisms.  

Daniel is investigating other potential remedies for the future including streaming it out or using an external nanny agent to recover logs.  Whatever we decide on, I hope we can use just that mechanism.

@paulcastro 

Hi Jason.  The invoker needs the sentinel markers to be coordinated with the language container and since this is node (which already has this feature), it should be enabled as part of this PR.  We are planning on doing this along with Swift and Python.  The relevant code is in lines 295 and 311 of Invoker.scala.

On line 295, augment with

```
private val nodejs6ImageName = WhiskAction.containerImageName(NodeJS6Exec("", None), config.dockerRegistry, config.dockerImageTag)
```

and change line 311 to

```
val isNodeJs = con.image == nodejsImageName || con.image == nodejs6ImageName
```

That should work but a better version would be to create a Set of all image names that will have the sentinel marker and change to checking `con.image` for membership in such a set.

I will update the nodejs 6 container to contain the two new packages being added as part of issue #523.   I assume docs will need to be updated as well to include the nodejs 6 list of packages.  The list is currently the same right now outside of package versions (which I don't know if we even list) and Jade being renamed to Pug.
